cpu.description: The CPU (Central Processing Unit) is the brain of your computer
howToChoose: Consider your use case: Gaming needs 6-8 cores, content creation needs 8-16 cores
Intel CPUs: Better for gaming (i5-13600K, i7-14700K). AMD CPUs: Better value and multitasking (Ryzen 5 5600X, Ryzen 9 7900X)
Check socket compatibility with your motherboard (Intel: LGA1700, AMD: AM5, AM4)
Higher clock speeds (GHz) = faster single-core performance
More cores = better multitasking and productivity
cpu.gaming: Ryzen 7 5800X3D is best value for gaming. Intel i5-13600K for high refresh rate
cpu.productivity: AMD Ryzen 9 7950X or Intel i9-13900K for heavy workloads

gpu.description: The GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) renders graphics and is crucial for gaming
howToChoose: Match GPU to your monitor resolution: 1080p = RTX 3060/RX 6600, 1440p = RTX 4060 Ti/RX 6750 XT, 4K = RTX 4080/RX 7900 XTX
NVIDIA: Better ray tracing, DLSS upscaling. AMD: Better value, more VRAM
Check GPU length fits in your case (usually 300-350mm)
Ensure PSU has enough wattage (add 150W buffer)
More VRAM = better for high-res gaming and content creation (8GB minimum, 12GB+ recommended)
gpu.midRange: RTX 4060 Ti or RX 6750 XT ($350-$500) - 1440p gaming
gpu.contentCreation: RTX 4070 or higher for CUDA acceleration in Adobe/DaVinci Resolve

ram.description: RAM (Memory) temporarily stores data for quick access by the CPU
howToChoose: Gaming: 16GB minimum, 32GB recommended for 2024+
Content creation: 32GB minimum, 64GB+ for 4K video editing
Programming: 16GB minimum, 32GB for VMs and containers
Speed matters: DDR4 3200-3600MHz or DDR5 5600MHz+
Buy in pairs (2x8GB, 2x16GB) for dual-channel performance
Check motherboard QVL for compatibility

storage.description: Storage saves all your files, games, and operating system
howToChoose: SSD (Solid State Drive) for OS and programs - MUCH faster than HDD
NVMe M.2 SSD: Fastest (3500 MB/s), best for OS and games
SATA SSD: Good speed (550 MB/s), good value
HDD (Hard Drive): Slow but cheap bulk storage for files
Minimum: 500GB NVMe SSD. Recommended: 1TB NVMe + 2TB HDD
Gen 4 NVMe for fast loading (7000 MB/s) vs Gen 3 (3500 MB/s)
storage.gaming: 500GB-1TB NVMe SSD for games (modern games are 100-150GB each)
storage.contentCreation: 1TB NVMe Gen 4 for projects + 2-4TB HDD for storage

motherboard.description: The motherboard connects all components together
howToChoose: Match socket to CPU: Intel LGA1700 (13th/14th gen) or AMD AM5 (Ryzen 7000), AM4 (Ryzen 5000)
Choose chipset: B660/B760 (Intel budget), Z690/Z790 (Intel OC), B550 (AMD budget), X670 (AMD premium)
Form factor: ATX (standard), Micro-ATX (smaller), Mini-ITX (compact)
Check RAM slots (4 is standard), M.2 slots (2+ recommended), PCIe slots
Ensure BIOS is updated for your CPU generation
Good VRMs (power delivery) for overclocking
motherboard.intelPremium: Z690 or Z790 Motherboard ($200-$400) - Overclocking support

psu.description: The PSU (Power Supply Unit) provides power to all components
howToChoose: Calculate wattage: Add all component power + 150W buffer
80+ certification: Bronze (budget), Gold (recommended), Platinum (premium)
Modular: Fully modular (best cable management), semi-modular, non-modular
Don't cheap out! Bad PSU can damage components
Brands: Corsair, EVGA, Seasonic, Thermaltake are reliable
Typical needs: 450-550W (office), 650-750W (gaming), 850W+ (high-end)
psu.calculation: RTX 4080 (320W) + i7-13700K (190W) + others (50W) = 560W minimum, recommend 750W PSU

case.description: The case houses all components and provides cooling
howToChoose: Form factor matches motherboard: ATX case for ATX board, etc.
Check GPU clearance (usually need 300-350mm for modern GPUs)
Airflow: Mesh front panel > solid panel. Include 3-4 fans minimum
Cable management: Look for PSU shroud, cable routing holes, velcro straps
Front I/O: USB 3.0, USB-C, audio jacks on front panel
Personal preference: RGB, tempered glass, aesthetics
case.midRange: Mid-tower with mesh front, good cable management ($80-$130)
case.premium: Premium case with RGB, USB-C, excellent build quality ($150-$250)

cpuCooler.description: CPU cooler keeps your processor from overheating
howToChoose: Stock coolers: Fine for non-overclocked budget CPUs
Tower air coolers: Best value, quiet, reliable (Hyper 212, NH-D15)
AIO liquid coolers: Better cooling, looks cleaner, 240mm/280mm/360mm sizes
Check CPU TDP and cooler rating: i5 = 120W cooler, i7/i9 = 200W+ cooler
Ensure cooler height fits in case (usually <165mm for tower coolers)
Consider noise levels (dB rating)
cpuCooler.midRange: Tower cooler like Hyper 212 or AK400 ($30-$60)

questions: What PC do I need for studying?
qaDatabase.answer: For studying, I recommend a budget-friendly build with an Intel i3-12100 or AMD Ryzen 5 5600G (with integrated graphics), 16GB RAM, and 512GB SSD. This costs around $400-$550 and handles Microsoft Office, web browsing, video calls, and research perfectly. If you do programming or data analysis, upgrade to 32GB RAM and an i5-13400 ($700-$900 range).

For 1080p gaming, I recommend: Intel i5-12400F or Ryzen 5 5600 CPU, RTX 3060 or RX 6600 GPU, 16GB DDR4 RAM, 500GB NVMe SSD, and 550W PSU. This costs $700-$900 and runs all modern games at 60-120fps on high settings. For 1440p gaming, upgrade to RTX 4060 Ti and increase budget to $1200-$1500.

For 4K gaming at ultra settings, you need: Intel i7-14700K or AMD Ryzen 9 7900X, RTX 4080 or RX 7900 XTX, 32GB DDR5 6000MHz RAM, 2TB NVMe Gen 4 SSD, 850W Gold PSU, and 360mm AIO cooler. Budget: $2000-$3000. This delivers 60-120fps at 4K with ray tracing enabled in all games.

For video editing, I recommend: Intel i7-13700K or Ryzen 9 7900X (12+ cores), RTX 4060 Ti or 3060 12GB (GPU acceleration), 64GB DDR4 RAM (important!), 1TB NVMe Gen 4 + 2TB SSD storage, 750W Gold PSU, and 280mm AIO cooler. Budget: $1500-$2000. This handles 4K editing smoothly in Premiere Pro and DaVinci Resolve.

For 3D rendering and animation: AMD Ryzen 9 7950X (16 cores) or Intel i9-14900K, RTX 4070 Ti or 4080 (CUDA acceleration), 128GB DDR5 RAM (crucial for large scenes), 2TB NVMe + 4TB HDD, 1000W Gold PSU, 360mm AIO cooler, full tower case. Budget: $2500-$3500. Excellent for Blender, Cinema 4D, Maya, and ZBrush.

For web development and programming: Intel i5-13400 or Ryzen 5 5600X, 32GB DDR4 RAM (for running Docker/VMs), 1TB NVMe SSD, integrated graphics (or basic GPU), 550W PSU. Budget: $800-$1100. Perfect for VS Code, Docker, multiple browsers, Node.js servers, and databases. The 32GB RAM is key for running containers and VMs.

For machine learning and AI development: AMD Ryzen 9 7900X or Intel i9-13900K, RTX 4070 Ti or 4080 (CUDA cores essential for PyTorch/TensorFlow), 64GB DDR5 RAM, 2TB NVMe Gen 4 SSD, 850W Gold PSU. Budget: $2000-$3000. The NVIDIA GPU with CUDA is critical for training deep learning models efficiently.

For basic office work: Intel i3-12100 or Ryzen 3 4100, integrated graphics, 8-16GB RAM, 256-512GB SSD, 400-450W PSU. Budget: $350-$500. Perfect for Microsoft Office, email, web browsing, and video calls. Very quiet and energy-efficient.

CPU choice depends on use case: For GAMING, Intel i5-13600K or Ryzen 7 5800X3D are best value. For PRODUCTIVITY, Ryzen 9 7900X offers more cores. For BUDGET, i3-12100 or Ryzen 5 5600G with integrated graphics. Intel = slightly better gaming fps. AMD = better multitasking and value. Always check motherboard socket compatibility!

GPU depends on resolution: 1080p = RTX 3060 or RX 6600 ($200-$300). 1440p = RTX 4060 Ti or RX 6750 XT ($350-$500). 4K = RTX 4080 or RX 7900 XTX ($1000+). NVIDIA pros: Better ray tracing, DLSS, NVENC encoding. AMD pros: More VRAM, better value. For content creation, choose NVIDIA for CUDA acceleration.

questions: How much RAM do I need?
qaDatabase.answer: RAM requirements: GAMING = 16GB minimum, 32GB recommended for 2024+. VIDEO EDITING = 32-64GB. PROGRAMMING = 16-32GB (32GB if using Docker/VMs). OFFICE = 8-16GB. Speed: DDR4 3200-3600MHz or DDR5 5600MHz+. Always buy in pairs (2x8GB or 2x16GB) for dual-channel. DDR5 is 15-20% faster but more expensive.

ALWAYS get SSD for OS and main programs! NVMe M.2 SSD is fastest (3500-7000 MB/s) and best for games. Recommendations: BUDGET = 500GB NVMe ($35-$50). GAMING = 1TB NVMe ($70-$120). CONTENT = 1TB NVMe Gen 4 + 2TB HDD ($150). Modern games need 100-150GB each. Gen 4 NVMe (7000 MB/s) vs Gen 3 (3500 MB/s) - Gen 4 for fast loading.

Motherboard must match CPU socket! INTEL 13th/14th gen = LGA1700 socket. AMD Ryzen 7000 = AM5, Ryzen 5000 = AM4. Chipsets: B660/B760 (Intel budget), Z690/Z790 (Intel + overclocking), B550 (AMD budget), X670 (AMD premium). Key features: 4 RAM slots, 2+ M.2 slots, good VRMs. ATX = standard size, Micro-ATX = smaller.

PSU wattage = Total component power + 150W buffer. Examples: Office (350W) = 450W PSU. RTX 3060 gaming (400W) = 550W PSU. RTX 4070 gaming (550W) = 750W PSU. RTX 4080 high-end (650W) = 850W PSU. Get 80+ Gold for efficiency. Modular = better cables. Brands: Corsair, EVGA, Seasonic, Thermaltake. DON'T cheap out on PSU!

questions: Do I need a CPU cooler?
qaDatabase.answer: Stock coolers: OK for i3/i5 or Ryzen 5 non-X CPUs at stock speeds. Aftermarket coolers: REQUIRED for i7/i9, Ryzen 7/9, or overclocking. Tower air cooler ($30-$60) = great value, quiet (Hyper 212, AK400). AIO liquid ($100-$180) = better cooling, cleaner look, 240/280/360mm. Match cooling to CPU TDP: i5 = 120W cooler, i7 = 200W cooler, i9 = 250W+ cooler.

Compatibility checklist: 1) CPU socket matches motherboard (LGA1700, AM5, AM4). 2) RAM type matches (DDR4 or DDR5). 3) GPU fits in case (check length, usually <350mm). 4) PSU has enough watts (use calculator). 5) CPU cooler height fits case (usually <165mm). 6) Motherboard BIOS updated for CPU. Use PCPartPicker.com for automatic compatibility checking!

Budget PC builds: $350-$500 = Office (i3, 8GB RAM, integrated graphics). $700-$900 = 1080p Gaming (i5-12400F, RTX 3060, 16GB RAM). $1200-$1500 = 1440p Gaming (i5-13600K, RTX 4060 Ti, 32GB RAM). Best value tips: Get previous-gen CPUs (Ryzen 5000), buy used GPU (check warranty), wait for sales, prioritize SSD over HDD.

PC building is like adult LEGO! Steps: 1) Install CPU and RAM on motherboard. 2) Install CPU cooler. 3) Install motherboard in case. 4) Install PSU. 5) Install storage (SSD/HDD). 6) Install GPU. 7) Connect all power cables. 8) Connect front panel cables. 9) Turn on and install Windows. Watch YouTube tutorials first! Takes 2-3 hours first time. Not difficult, just be careful and read manuals.

Custom build PROS: 15-30% cheaper, choose exact parts, better quality components, learning experience, easier upgrades. CONS: Takes time, need research, no warranty on whole system. Pre-built PROS: Convenience, whole-system warranty, no building needed. CONS: 15-30% more expensive, often cheap PSU/RAM, proprietary parts, bloatware. Recommendation: Build custom if budget >$700. Buy pre-built if you want immediate plug-and-play.

Upgrade priority for GAMING: 1) GPU (biggest fps increase), 2) SSD (if still on HDD), 3) RAM (if <16GB), 4) CPU (if bottlenecking GPU), 5) Monitor. For PRODUCTIVITY: 1) RAM (if maxing out), 2) Storage/SSD, 3) CPU, 4) GPU. Check if CPU bottlenecks GPU first (search '[your CPU] + [your GPU] bottleneck'). Upgrade GPU if CPU usage <80% while gaming.

PC won't turn on checklist: 1) Check PSU switch is ON. 2) Reseat power cables (24-pin, 8-pin CPU, GPU power). 3) Reseat RAM (try one stick in slot 2). 4) Check front panel connectors on motherboard. 5) Remove GPU and try integrated graphics. 6) Check motherboard debug LEDs. 7) Breadboard test (motherboard outside case). If still stuck, one component may be DOA (dead on arrival).

Monitor guide: BUDGET GAMING = 1080p 144Hz IPS ($150-$200). MID-RANGE = 1440p 144Hz-165Hz IPS ($250-$350). HIGH-END = 1440p 240Hz or 4K 144Hz ($500-$800). Match to your GPU! RTX 3060 = 1080p-1440p. RTX 4060 Ti = 1440p. RTX 4080 = 4K. Panel types: IPS (best colors), VA (best contrast), TN (fastest but bad colors). Get at least 144Hz for gaming!

Peripherals guide: KEYBOARD: Mechanical ($70-$150) = better feel, customizable, durable. Switches: Red (linear), Brown (tactile), Blue (clicky). MOUSE: Wired gaming mouse ($40-$80) = low latency. Look for 12000+ DPI, good sensor (Logitech, Razer). HEADSET: Wireless gaming headset ($80-$150) or get separate headphones ($100) + mic ($50) for better quality. Don't overspend - focus budget on PC first!
